docs.lead_paragraph: To the delight of Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign, the White House slammed her today over her new television advertisement charging that single mothers, veterans, and Americans lacking health insurance are "invisible" to an uncaring President Bush.
docs.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton's advisers quickly flagged the White House comments on a campaign Web site.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''World's Best Medical Care?'' (editorial, Aug. 12):

headline.main: Health Care in America: Let's Heal It

docs.abstract: Seven letters comment on Aug 12 editorial about medical care in US; Jack Scharf applauds editorial for accurate summary of medical care in US; Michael Golding says best investment he ever made is enrolling in boutique medical practice; Eduardo Munoz Perou describes excellent and free medical care he received when he fell ill during visit to Spain; Rita Tobin holds that national health care plan would put dollars and technology toward standardizing treatment; Dr Joel Brence says it is not surprising that nation that makes economy its ultimate bottom line has health care system that favors the wealthy; Dr Donald Mender holds editorial misses central flaw in American health care system--institutionalized cost shifting; Ivan Beggs notes that many elderly in US lose their homes and assets to pay for medical care; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''World's Best Medical Care?'' (editorial, Aug. 12):

docs.lead_paragraph: Six underwater turbines that were installed in the East River near Roosevelt Island and are supposed to turn the river's currents into electricity have been shut down for repairs and a basic redesign, Anthony DePalma reports. It has been a rough eight months for Verdant Power, the company that owns the equipment. Days after the first two turbines were lowered into the water, the East River's powerful currents sheared off the tips of several blades. New blades -- made of a cast aluminum that theoretically would hold up better -- replaced the ones that were broken and were also installed on the four other turbines.Together, the turbines are capable of producing about 1,000 kilowatt hours a day of clean electricity.But the East River tides have proved too formidable even for the stronger blades, putting excessive strain on the bolts that hold them to the turbine hubs, so all six turbines have been shut for repairs. A and a video accompany Mr. DePalma's article; an earlier video, in January, examined how the turbines work.

headline.main: Morning Buzz: Stalled East River Turbines, a Stronger Ethics Panel, School Translators and More
